title: LLMs and Use of Metaphor
text:
LLMs and Use of Metaphor
In this week‚Äôs class we had a first glance at how LLMs are good at language and communication with humans in different scenarios and manners, but most of the examples we saw involved casual daily language. For example, when we talked about the word ‚Äúbank‚Äù in class, there were many meanings associated with ‚Äúbank‚Äù such as a financial institution, plane banking, or basketball bank shot, but they are still in common expressions. I am interested in whether LLM is good at language structures that add complexity in meaning, such as metaphors or idioms.

Part I: LLM‚Äôs ability in understanding existing metaphors.
I found a list of metaphors from Udemy and asked LLM to explain them.
The Prompt I gave to Chatgpt (GPT-5) was :
Explain what each of the sentence means:

I could eat a horse
It all went pear shaped
It‚Äôs no skin off my nose
She is an open book: she has nothing to hide.
He wears his heart on his sleeve
It‚Äôs showtime
These are the dog days of summer
You‚Äôre building castles in the air
I was a million miles away
He marches to his own drummer
Splitting hairs
Nitpicking
The whole enchilada
A nine-to-five job
Hit the books
LLM‚Äôs response (number four should be omitted as the answer was accidentally revealed):



Chatgpt response on 15 idioms


LLM did well in recognizing metaphors and explaining them with the correct meaning. This is not surprising to me as we have discussed in class and also read from Walfram‚Äôs blog that LLM is trained to predict the most likely word that happens next. It is also trained on a wide dataset, so anything that has long been published online would be easily searched through and recognized by LLMs.


Part II: LLM‚Äôs ability in understanding newly created metaphors.
I was also curious if I make up a metaphor, would LLM infer it from the emotional context and the wide range of human language convention?
I wrote these metaphors and sent to LLM: - Your heart is a stone - The wind is roaring - The store is a warehouse



Chatgpt understanding on metaphors I created


It still seemed to understand them really well. I think this is not surprising because LLMs are trained to predict the meaning behind languages. My metaphors will be easy for humans to understand, so it should be the same for LLMs.


Part III: Can humans understand LLM created idioms?
I was then curious about LLM‚Äôs ability to create metaphors and if humans can understand them.



GPT created metaphor


I interviewed three friends and they were all able to understand these metaphors and expressions. These metaphors seem pretty easy to be understood and also carry the depth and arts of expression. This makes me wonder about LLM‚Äôs ability in creative and novel writing. I will go further from there next week.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
